thread.title: H.S. football: North 1, Group 2 battle could go down to wire - Football
thread.title_full: H.S. football: North 1, Group 2 battle could go down to wire - Football - NorthJersey.com

author: MARK J. CZERWINSKI
title: H.S. football: North 1, Group 2 battle could go down to wire - Football
text:
The playoff races are starting to heat up, but few are percolating as much as North 1, Group 2.
Buy this photo Danny Mullin and Lakeland face two Group 4 unbeatens down the stretch. Three quality football teams – Lakeland, Westwood and Waldwick/Midland Park – are tied for the eighth spot with two weeks remaining, and none have a particularly easy ride ahead.
Westwood (3-3), the defending champion, snapped a three-game losing streak last week against Fort Lee. On Friday night, it hosts No. 3 Ramsey (4-2), a team that has won four of its past five, including Friday’s 28-20 upset of Ridgefield Park.
Waldwick/Midland Park (4-2) has dropped two of its past three. The Warriors face Manchester this weekend, but draw unbeaten Rutherford in two weeks with a possible spot on the line.
Lakeland (4-2) has the hardest road by far, with a pair of unbeaten Group 4 teams on tap. The Lancers face Wayne Valley (6-0) on Friday night and NV/Old Tappan a week later, so they’re going to need a major upset and/or a box full of residual points to crash the party.
NORTH 1, GROUP 1: Last week’s loss to Becton was a big blow to Saddle Brook (4-2), dropping the Falcons out of the top eight in one of North Jersey’s most competitive brackets. They need a big bounce-back win Friday night against North Arlington (2-4), a team trying to stop a four-game losing streak and keep its flickering North 2, Group 1 hopes alive.
Cresskill (4-2) climbed back into the seventh spot by beating No. 2 Park Ridge, and have a lot more power points on the table Friday when they face No. 3 Hasbrouck Heights (5-1).
NORTH 1, GROUP 5: The pressure is on Hackensack (3-2) in Friday’s matchup with No. 1 Ridgewood (5-1). The Comets have slipped back into the ninth slot, but really can shuffle this race with a victory over a Ridgewood team riding a five-game winning streak.
NON-PUBLIC GROUP 4: Paramus Catholic (3-3) is finally back in the mix, jumping all the way to No. 5 after last week’s win over Friendship Academy (D.C.). Two straight wins has salvaged PC’s season, and it still has a shot at an opening-round home game if it can pull off a huge upset Friday night against an IMG Academy (Fla.) team that already has beaten Bergen Catholic and St. Joseph.
This bracket is going to look much different next week after No. 2 St. Joseph (5-2) plays No. 4 Bergen Catholic (4-2) on Saturday in Oradell. BC follows that up with a game against No. 1 Don Bosco, so the Crusaders will have a major impact on how this race finally shakes out.
